Docs.summary: Represents a control that contains multiple items that share the same space on the screen.

remarks.format:
## Remarks The TabControl is useful for minimizing screen space usage while allowing an application to expose a large amount of data. A TabControl consists of multiple <xref:System.Windows.Controls.TabItem> objects that share the same screen space. Only one <xref:System.Windows.Controls.TabItem> in a TabControl is visible at a time. When a user selects the tab of a <xref:System.Windows.Controls.TabItem>, the contents of that <xref:System.Windows.Controls.TabItem> become visible and the contents of the other <xref:System.Windows.Controls.TabItem> objects are hidden.
TabControl is an <xref:System.Windows.Controls.ItemsControl>, which means it can contain a collection of objects of any type (such as string, image, or panel). For more information, see the <xref:System.Windows.Controls.ItemsControl> class.
## Customizing the TabControl Control To apply the same property settings to multiple TabControl controls, use the <xref:System.Windows.FrameworkElement.Style%2A> property. You can modify the default <xref:System.Windows.Controls.ControlTemplate> to give the control a unique appearance. For more information about creating a <xref:System.Windows.Controls.ControlTemplate>, see [Customizing the Appearance of an Existing Control by Creating a ControlTemplate](../Topic/Customizing%20the%20Appearance%20of%20an%20Existing%20Control%20by%20Creating%20a%20ControlTemplate.md). To see the parts and states that are specific to the TabControl, see [TabControl Styles and Templates](../Topic/TabControl%20Styles%20and%20Templates.md).
Dependency properties for this control might be set by the control’s default style. If a property is set by a default style, the property might change from its default value when the control appears in the application. The default style is determined by which desktop theme is used when the application is running. For more information, see [Default WPF Themes](http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkID=158252).
> [!NOTE] > Setting a visual property will only have an effect if that property is both present in TabControl control's default template and is set by using a . You can find a list of visual properties in the "Changing the Visual Structure of a Control" section in [Customizing the Appearance of an Existing Control by Creating a ControlTemplate](../Topic/Customizing%20the%20Appearance%20of%20an%20Existing%20Control%20by%20Creating%20a%20ControlTemplate.md).
## Examples The following example creates a TabControl and binds the <xref:System.Windows.Controls.TextBlock> in the second <xref:System.Windows.Controls.TabItem> to a <xref:System.Windows.Controls.TextBox> in the first <xref:System.Windows.Controls.TabItem>.
[!code-xml[ControlContentOverviewSnippets#16](~/add/codesnippet/xaml/ControlContentOverviewSnippets/Window1.xaml#16)]

MemberSignature.Value: .method public hidebysig specialname rtspecialname instance void .ctor() cil managed

Docs.summary: Initializes a new instance of the .class.
Gets a composite string that specifies how to format the contents of the objects if they are displayed as strings.
Docs.value: A composite string that specifies how to format the contents of the objects if they are displayed as strings.

remarks.format:
## Remarks ContentStringFormat can be a predefined, composite, or custom string format. For more information about string formats, see [Formatting Types](../Topic/Formatting%20Types%20in%20the%20.NET%20Framework.md). If you set the <xref:System.Windows.Controls.TabControl.ContentTemplate%2A> or <xref:System.Windows.Controls.TabControl.ContentTemplateSelector%2A> of a <xref:System.Windows.Controls.TabControl>, the ContentStringFormat property is ignored.
## Examples The following example binds a <xref:System.Windows.Controls.TabControl> to a collection of `Student` objects. The `Student` class has a `Name` property, a collection of `Course` objects, and implements the <xref:System.IFormattable.ToString%2A?displayProperty=fullName> method to return either the `Name` of the student or a string that lists the student's courses. The example uses <xref:System.Windows.Controls.HeaderedContentControl.HeaderStringFormat%2A?displayProperty=fullName> to put a student's name in the <xref:System.Windows.Controls.HeaderedContentControl.Header%2A> of each <xref:System.Windows.Controls.TabItem> (which inherits from <xref:System.Windows.Controls.HeaderedContentControl>), and the ContentStringFormat to display the course list for each student in the Content of the <xref:System.Windows.Controls.TabItem>.
[!code-xml[ContentStringSnippets#TabControl](~/add/codesnippet/xaml/ContentStringSnippets/Window1.xaml#tabcontrol)]
The following example implements the <xref:System.IFormattable.ToString%2A?displayProperty=fullName> method to return either the `Name` of the student or a string that lists the student's courses.
[!code-cs[ContentStringSnippets#TabControlToString](~/add/codesnippet/csharp/ContentStringSnippets/Window1.xaml.cs#tabcontroltostring)] [!code-vb[ContentStringSnippets#TabControlToString](~/add/codesnippet/visualbasic/contentstringsnippets/window1.xaml.vb#tabcontroltostring)]

MemberSignature.Value: .field public static initonly class System.Windows.DependencyProperty ContentStringFormatProperty

remarks.format: ## Remarks ## XAML Attribute Usage ``` ``` ## XAML Property Element Usage ## XAML Values *ResourceExtension* One of the following: `StaticResource`, or `DynamicResource`. See [XAML Resources](../Topic/XAML%20Resources.md). *TemplateResourceKey* The key that identifies the template being requested. The key refers to an existing resource in a . > [!NOTE] > Property element syntax is technically possible, but not recommended. See [Inline Styles and Templates](../Topic/Inline%20Styles%20and%20Templates.md). ## Dependency Property Information ||| |-|-| |Identifier field|| |Metadata properties set to `true`|None| ## Examples The following example creates two objects. The called `contentTemplate` is assigned to the ContentTemplate of the and the called `tabItemTemplate` is assigned to the of the second . All objects contain the white rectangle defined in `contentTemplate`, except the second , which has a gray rectangle, as defined in `tabItemTemplate`. [!code-xml[TabControlContentTemplate_snip#1](~/add/codesnippet/xaml/tabcontrolcontenttemplate_snip/page1.xaml#1)] [!code-xml[TabControlContentTemplate_snip#1](~/add/codesnippet/xaml/p-system.windows.control_298_1.xaml)] [!code-xml[TabControlContentTemplate_snip#2](~/add/codesnippet/xaml/tabcontrolcontenttemplate_snip/page1.xaml#2)] [!code-xml[TabControlContentTemplate_snip#2](~/add/codesnippet/xaml/p-system.windows.control_298_2.xaml)]

MemberSignature.Value: .field public static initonly class System.Windows.DependencyProperty ContentTemplateProperty

Docs.summary: Identifies the dependency property.
Gets or sets a that provides custom logic for choosing the template that is used to display the content of the control.

remarks.format: ## Remarks Typically, you create a when you have more than one for the same type of objects and you want to supply your own logic to choose a to apply based on the properties of each data object. Note that if you have objects of different types, you can set the property on the . If you do that, then there is no need to create a . Furthermore, if you have objects of the same type but with different properties, you can also consider using a or a data converter. For more information, see [Data Templating Overview](../Topic/Data%20Templating%20Overview.md). To create a template selector, create a class that inherits from and override the method. After your class is defined, you can assign an instance of the class to the template selector property of your element. If both the ContentTemplateSelector and the properties are set, then this property is ignored. ## XAML Attribute Usage ``` ``` ## XAML Property Element Usage ``` ``` ## XAML Values *ResourceExtension* One of the following: `StaticResource`, or `DynamicResource`. See [XAML Resources](../Topic/XAML%20Resources.md). *DataTemplateSelectorClassKey* The key that identifies the selector implementation being requested. The key refers to a derived class that implements a practical override. For information about how to map your custom class, see [XAML Namespaces and Namespace Mapping for WPF XAML](../Topic/XAML%20Namespaces%20and%20Namespace%20Mapping%20for%20WPF%20XAML.md). You can also programmatically add an instance of your class as a resource to a resource dictionary. *MyDataTemplateSelectorImplementation* A class derived from and overrides . For information about how to map your custom class, see [XAML Namespaces and Namespace Mapping for WPF XAML](../Topic/XAML%20Namespaces%20and%20Namespace%20Mapping%20for%20WPF%20XAML.md). ## Dependency Property Information ||| |-|-| |Identifier field|| |Metadata properties set to `true`|None| ## Examples The following example uses the ContentTemplateSelector property to display the content of a differently, depending on the hometown of the selected person. [!code-xml[TabControlContentTemplateSelector#1](~/add/codesnippet/xaml/TabControlContentTemplateSelector/Window1.xaml#1)] [!code-xml[TabControlContentTemplateSelector#2](~/add/codesnippet/xaml/TabControlContentTemplateSelector/Window1.xaml#2)] [!code-cs[TabControlContentTemplateSelector#3](~/add/codesnippet/csharp/TabControlContentTemplateSelector/Window1.xaml.cs#3)] [!code-vb[TabControlContentTemplateSelector#3](~/add/codesnippet/visualbasic/TabControlContentTemplateSelector/Window1.xaml.vb#3)]

remarks.format: ## Remarks The control raises the <xref:System.Windows.FrameworkElement.IsInitialized%2A> event by calling <xref:System.Windows.UIElement.RaiseEvent%2A>. For more information, see [Routed Events Overview](../Topic/Routed%20Events%20Overview.md).

MemberSignature.Value: .method familyhidebysig virtual instance void OnItemsChanged(class System.Collections.Specialized.NotifyCollectionChangedEventArgs e) cil managed

Docs.param: The event data for the event.
Docs.summary: Called to update the current selection when items change.

MemberSignature.Value: .method familyhidebysig virtual instance void OnKeyDown(class System.Windows.Input.KeyEventArgs e) cil managed

Docs.summary: Provides class handling for the routed event that occurs when the user presses a key.

remarks.format: ## Remarks This implementation marks the <xref:System.Windows.ContentElement.KeyDown> event as handled by setting the <xref:System.Windows.RoutedEventArgs.Handled%2A> property of the event data to `true` when the user presses CTRL+TAB, CTRL+SHIFT+TAB, HOME, or END to navigate between <xref:System.Windows.Controls.TabItem> objects. Otherwise, this implementation does not change the handled state (the <xref:System.Windows.RoutedEventArgs.Handled%2A> property) of the <xref:System.Windows.ContentElement.KeyDown> event data.

MemberSignature.Value: .method familyhidebysig virtual instance void OnSelectionChanged(class System.Windows.Controls.SelectionChangedEventArgs e) cil managed

Docs.summary: Raises the routed event.

remarks.format:
## Remarks The <xref:System.Windows.Controls.TabControl> updates the <xref:System.Windows.Controls.TabControl.SelectedContent%2A>, <xref:System.Windows.Controls.TabControl.SelectedContentTemplate%2A>, and <xref:System.Windows.Controls.TabControl.SelectedContentTemplateSelector%2A> properties to the objects used by the currently selected <xref:System.Windows.Controls.TabItem>.
The control raises the <xref:System.Windows.Controls.Primitives.Selector.SelectionChanged> event by calling <xref:System.Windows.UIElement.RaiseEvent%2A>. For more information, see [Routed Events Overview](../Topic/Routed%20Events%20Overview.md).

Docs.summary: Gets the content of the currently selected .
Docs.value: The content of the currently selected . The default is .

remarks.format: ## Remarks This property is updated to reference the of the active when the tab selection changes. The of the uses the property to bind the property to this property. If you create a new for the , be sure to the bind the property to this property by setting the property to "SelectedContent" or by using [TemplateBinding Markup Extension](../Topic/TemplateBinding%20Markup%20Extension.md). ## XAML Attribute Usage ``` ``` ## Dependency Property Information ||| |-|-| |Identifier field|| |Metadata properties set to `true`|None| ## Examples The following example uses the SelectedContent property to get the `Person` in the currently selected . Setting the property to "SelectedContent" creates aliases to the SelectedContent, , and properties.
